results.title: Harvesting
results.creator_credit: Arthur Lamothe, Guy L. Cote, Marcel Martin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A visual poem about the wheat harvest on the vast Canadian prairies. Here, reality is horizon-wide fields of grain that must be cut and threshed by the combines before frost lays the crop to waste. The images suggest a strange but magnificent military maneuver as a phalanx of giant machines lumbers across the golden acres.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arthur Lamothe, Guy L. Cote, Marcel Martin and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Harvest
results.creator_credit: Fergus McDonell, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A portrayal of the kind of problems a rural clergyman is called upon to solve and how they add meaning to his work. In this film, Rev. Edward Dawson is asked by a farm couple to advise their son George against leaving the land in favor of a factory job in the city. Mr. Dawson finds a parallel between George’s problem and his own, for he too must choose between a city church and his rural calling. He is given cause to re-examine the stewardship with which he is entrusted and in it finds an answer both for himself and for George.

results.title: Harvest of the gulfs
results.creator_credit: John Leake, Peter Dimond, Motion Picture Associates and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This film traces the research being undertaken by the South Australian Department of Fisheries into the life cycle, habitat and movements of the Western King Prawn in the South Australian gulf waters.

results.title: Harvest
results.creator_credit: Carroll Ballard and U.S.A Department of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Farming in the United States: with the population increase more food must be produced even though more land is being taken up for city and urban expansion. The student population is increasing in universities and agricultural colleges where the study of the sciences associated with modern farming are undergoing rapid change. This leads to a reduction of farm problems and bigger yields with the aid of new chemicals and mechanical implements. However, the farmer is still at the mercy of the weather. Culminates in a harvest sequence.

results.title: Harold's fairy tale
results.creator_credit: Gene Deitch, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Harold draws an enchanted garden, only to discover that nothing can grow there because of the machinations of a giant witch. With the aid of his purple crayon, he defeats the witch and makes the garden bloom again. A delightful animated story for children. Based on the book by Crockett Johnson.

results.title: Harold and the purple crayon
results.creator_credit: David Piel, Robert Sagalyn, Stanley Flink and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: One evening, Harold decides to go for a walk in the moonlight, but there isn’t any moon, so he takes his purple crayon and draws one. As Harold draws his way out of adventure, children become fascinated by the wondrous magic of his purple crayon. Based on the book by Crockett Johnson. Narrated by Norman Rose. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Harnessed flames
results.brief_description: The manufacture of iron and steel at Port Kembla; the conversion of coal into coke in the enormous coke ovens; the smelting of iron ore in the blast furnaces to produce cast iron; the use of molten iron and scrap metal in the open hearth furnaces to produce high-grade steel; the rolling and stamping of white-hot ingots reducing the material to convenient shapes and sizes. The film concludes with information on products being planned for the “future” as part of the Australian steel industry. No credits available.

results.title: Harness the wind
results.creator_credit: Sidney Goldsmith, Derek Lamb and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The wind is one of the strongest natural forces around us. Because it is generated by temperature differences in air masses, wind power is in fact a form of solar energy. This film traces the history of man’s attempts to control and utilize wind energy, and projects into the future to visualize the potential of wind-power technology. (Awards: Tokyo; New York; Ottawa)

results.title: Harlequin
results.brief_description: A series of animated stories by various students at the Newton Creative Arts Center. Called the Yellow Ball Workshop and instructed by Yvonne Anderson some of the shorts are: Red Cat by Daniel Sterne; Fountain Fantasie by Tamara Hurwitz; Evolution Now by Fred Allen; A Joy Ride by Pamela Gilfillan and Rock of Ages by Stephen Wren.

results.title: Harlem Wednesday
results.creator_credit: Faith Hubley, John Hubley, Edward Harrison and Story Board
results.brief_description: Using the paintings of the American artist Gregario Prestopino, the camera explores life in Harlem throughout the day and late into the night. With jazz accompaniment and clever editing, the film epitomises the life of the people and the atmosphere of their environment. Harlem Wednesday won an award at the Venice Film Festival.
